1. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the neurology clinic by his parents due to delayed motor milestones and persistent involuntary eye movements noticed since infancy. He was born full-term after an uneventful pregnancy but never achieved head control or could sit independently like his peers. The parents report episodes of hypotonia alternating with spasticity in his limbs, and progressive difficulty with swallowing. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle who died in early childhood from an undiagnosed neurological disorder. On examination, he demonstrates nystagmus, generalized hypotonia, and increased deep tendon reflexes. Brain MRI reveals diffuse hypomyelination of the cerebral white matter consistent with a leukodystrophy. Genetic testing subsequently confirms a mutation in the PLP1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher Disease. Supportive care and multidisciplinary interventions are initiated to manage his evolving neurological symptoms.
